front.title: PCEP Extensions for Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (BFD)

abstract.t: This document describes the extensions to the Path Computation Element (PCE) Communication Protocol (PCEP) to notify Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (BFD) parameters for Label Switched Paths (LSPs) from PCE to Path Computation Client (PCC) for PCE-initiated LSP. The extensions include BFD protocol parameters and allow PCC to support BFD for PCE-Initiated LSP. Further, support for bi-directional co-routed BFD channel is provided.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: describes the applicability of Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (BFD) in relation to Label Switched Path (LSP) Ping for detecting rapidly a Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS) LSP data plane failure. It also describes procedures for using BFD in MPLS environment. The LSP (for which BFD is used to detect failure) can be a bidirectional LSP or an unidirectional LSP (so long as there is some return path). In case of bidirectional LSP, it should be noted that, if the path from ingress LSR to egress LSR is not co-routed with the path from egress LSR to ingress LSR, the failure to deliver BFD control packets from egress LSR to ingress LSR can lead to false negatives, making ingress LSR deduces that the LSP has failed. proposes a solution to instruct the egress to use an explicit path for its BFD control packets associated with a particular BFD session.

The Path Computation Element Communication Protocol (PCEP) defines the mechanisms for the communication between a Path Computation Client (PCC) and a Path Computation Element (PCE), or between two PCEs. describes a set of extensions to PCEP to provide stateful control for stateful PCE.

introduces the procedure of PCE-initiated LSPs under the stateful PCE model where the setup and teardown is initiated by the PCE, without the need for local configuration on the PCC, thus allowing for a dynamic network. The PCC creates the LSP using the attributes communicated by the PCE (and local values for any unspecified parameters) and initiate setup of the LSP. BFD session for the PCE-initiated LSP can also be created dynamically based on the BFD parameters set by the PCE at the same time as LSP creation without a need for local configuration on the PCC. Note that for the explicitly routed LSP, it is likely that the shortest return path to the ingress would not follow the same path as the LSP in the forward direction and is thus would face false positive. As discussed earlier, defines a mechanism to form bi-directional co-routed associated channel for BFD sessions.

This document describes the extensions to the PCEP to include BFD parameters for LSPs from PCE to PCC for PCE-initiated LSP. The PCC would further set up BFD session for the PCE-Initiated LSP. Apart for setup, PCE could also modify or remove BFD session for PCE-Initiated LSP.

The PCE could set the BFD protocol parameters, such as detection time multiplier, desired Min TX Interval, required Min RX Interval for PCE-initiated LSP. In case PCE does not explicitly set these, then the PCC could set these values from a local template or configuration (at PCC).

This document proposes two modes to bootstrap BFD session for PCE-Initiated LSP, one without the use of LSP-ping where the PCE sets the BFD Discriminators for the forward and reverse LSPs. The second involves the use of LSP Ping by Ingress as usual.

section.t: BFD: Bidirectional Forwarding Detection
LSP: Label Switching Path

The following term is defined in : PCE-initiated LSP: LSP that is instantiated as a result of a request from the PCE.

section.title: Bootstrapping BFD Session
section.t: At the time of PCE-initiation of the LSP, PCE could also request the setup of the BFD session for the LSP to monitor the data plane. The LSP could be uni-directional or bi-directional. In case of bi-directional LSP, a co-routed bi-directional BFD session is setup.

section.title: Bootstrapping BFD session without LSP Ping
section.t: BFD for MPLS LSP uses LSP Ping to carry the local discriminators to bootstrap the BFD session in order to associate the FEC representing the LSP with the BFD session indicated by the discriminators. But the PCE could also be used to allocate and set the pair of discriminators at the Ingress and Egress, in which case the initial LSP Ping is not needed. This mode is applicable only for the double-sided bi-directional LSP that are initiated at the Ingress PCC and the Egress PCC, explicitly by the PCE.

Consider, the forward LSP from the ingress LSR to egress LSR is called LSP1. The PCE initiates LSP1 at the Ingress. Further PCE also initiates the creation of reverse LSP on egress LSR according to the co-routed path from egress LSR to ingress LSR. The LSP is called as LSP2.

PCE also updates to the ingress LSR and egress LSR to set up BFD session for LSP1 and LSP2 by the PCEP extension (as per this document), by setting the pair of BFD discriminators at the ingress and egress PCCs. Thus, it is not necessary to send LSP ping to bootstrap the BFD session. The 'my discriminator' in BFD control packets along LSP1 is 'your discriminator' in BFD control packets along LSP2 and vice versa.
By this method the same BFD session is set up not only for LSP1 but also LSP2.
The mechanism by which a PCE allocates the BFD discriminator is out of scope of this document.

section.title: Bootstrapping BFD session with LSP Ping
section.t: As per , a BFD session is bootstrapped using LSP Ping. To establish a BFD session, an LSP Ping Echo request message carry the local discriminator assigned by the ingress LSR for the BFD session. The egress LSR respond with an LSP Ping Echo reply message that carries the local discriminator assigned by it for the BFD session. The BFD control packet uses the discriminator as exchanges via the LSP Ping Echo request and Echo reply messages.
During the LSP initiation, PCE can also update the BFD parameters, the BFD discriminators are allocated by LSR and not set by the PCE.

dhruv.t: defines the BFD Reverse Path TLV as an extension to LSP Ping and proposes that it to be used to instruct the egress BFD peer to use specified path for its BFD control packets associated with the particular BFD session. In this way the forward and reverse directions of the BFD session can form a bi-directional co-routed associated channel.

PCE notify ingress LSR to set up BFD session for LSP1 carrying the FEC information about the reverse LSP, LSP2. The information received by ingress LSR via PCEP can be set to the BFD Reverse Path TLV in the LSP Ping message. Following the procedure defined in [draft-ietf-mpls-bfd-directed-02] the BFD session would be a bi- directional co-routed channel and no false detection would be notified.
PCE notify Egress LSR to set up BFD session for LSP2 following the same process above.
By this method two BFD sessions are set up for LSP1 and LSP2 independently.

section.title: TLVs of PCEP Extensions for BFD
BFD Reverse Path TLV
section.t: The BFD Reverse Path TLV provides BFD parameters used to indicate the reverse path for BFD session.
This is an optional TLV defined for the LSPA Object. This TLV is included in the LSPA Object with PCUpd message.
The format of the BFD Reverse Path TLV is shown in the following figure:
BFD Reverse Path TLV Type is 2 octets in length and the value is to be assigned by IANA.
Length is 2 octets in length and defines the length in octets of the Reverse Path field.
Reverse Path refers to Reverse Path defined in BFD Reverse Path TLV in I-D.ietf-mpls-bfd-directed .

section.title: BFD Generic TLV
section.t: The BFD Generic TLV provides BFD generic parameters of BFD session.
This is an optional TLV defined for the LSPA Object. This TLV is included in the LSPA Object with PCInitiate or PCUpd message.

section.title: BFD Authentication TLV
section.t: The BFD Authentication TLV provides BFD authentication parameters of BFD session.
This is an optional TLV defined for the LSPA Object. This TLV is included in the LSPA Object with PCInitiate or PCUpd message.
The format of the BFD Generic Path TLV is shown in the following figure:
BFD Authentication TLV Type is 2 octets in length and the value is to be assigned by IANA.
